trial_identification.studytitle: The effect of intravenous lidocaine infusion on the pain after laparoscopic assisted distal gastrectomy
trial_identification.scientifictitle: In patients undergoing laparoscopic assisted distal gastrectomy, is intravenous lidocaine infusion effective in reducing post-operative pain?

conditions.healthcondition: pain following laparoscopic assisted distal gastrectomy

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Other diseases of the mouth, teeth, oesophagus, digestive system including liver and colon

interventions.interventions: Intravenous (IV) lidocaine infusion:group: IV administration of 1mg/ml lidocaine was performed 2 minute before orotracheal intubation. Patients in arm1 received an IV bolus injection of lidocaine (1.5 mg/kg) followed by a continuous IV infusion of lidocaine at 2 mg/kg/hr during the operation (150-180 min).
interventions.comparator: Control group: patients in control group received an intravenous bolus injection of normal saline (1.5 ml/kg) followed by a continuous IV infusion of saline at 2 ml/kg/hr during the operation (150-180 min).

primaryOutcome.outcome: Pain score assessed using 100 point-visual analogue scale

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Frequency to push the button of patient controlled analgesia machine recordedy computerized patient controlled analgesia machine

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: patients undergoin laparoscopic assisted distal gastrectomy
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: body weight lower than 45 kg or greater than 100 kg, history of severe underlying cardiovascular, pulmonary, renal or hepatic disease, or allergy to local anaesthetics

trial_design.concealment: The details of the series are kept in a set of sealed envelopes, each bearing only the case number on the outside. After admitting into the operating room and just before the induction of anaesthesia, the numbered envelope was opened and the card inside determined which group the patient would be affiliated to.
trial_design.sequence: Randomization into one of the two groups was based on Excel random-number generation.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Intravenous lidocaine infusion in various type of surgery is known to effective in reducing post-operative pain, analgesic requirements, the stress response and lengthens the period to first post-operative analgesic requirement. We hypothesized that intravenous lidocaine infusion reduce the pain after laparoscopic surgery. Therefore we performed a study to investigate the effectiveness of lidocaine on pain after laparoscopic assisted distal gastrectomy. .
